Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that U.S. Rep. Elijah Cummings was not in Italy in late July 2019.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Cummings was dining at a fancy restaurant in Venice with other lawmakers.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or credible source to back up the claim.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the alternative explanation that Cummings was not in Italy but was thousands of miles away.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Cummings was in Italy without any evidence or proof.
Understate: There is no understatement bias present in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by spreading misinformation and false rumors about Cummings' whereabouts.
